header_summary:
Keyser Söze and others have initiated discussions to significantly improve Bitcoin's wallet interoperability and security through two proposed Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs), aimed at creating a standardized, secure, and interoperable framework for wallet backups and transfers. The first proposal introduces a CBOR-based format for serializing wallet data, focusing on extensibility and deterministic encoding, while the second proposal suggests a secure and versioned container for encrypted wallet payloads, utilizing Argon2id for encryption. These drafts are currently under review and open for community feedback ([Standard Encrypted Wallet Payload](https://gist.github.com/KeysSoze/7109a7f0455897b1930f851bde6337e3), [Standard Wallet Encryption Envelope](https://gist.github.com/KeysSoze/866d009ccd082edf6802df240154b20d)).

The release candidate for Bitcoin Core version v30.0rc1 has been announced by fanquake, marking a significant milestone towards the new major version release. This update includes preliminary release notes and a testing guide, with binaries and source code available for review. The development community is encouraged to provide feedback on this candidate through the designated issue tracker on GitHub, with the aim of finalizing version v30.0 ([Bitcoin Core's official page](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-30.0/test.rc1/), [GitHub](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/tree/v30.0rc1), [Release Notes Draft](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/bitcoin-devwiki/wiki/v30.0-Release-Notes-Draft), [Testing Guide](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/bitcoin-devwiki/wiki/30.0-Release-Candidate-Testing-Guide)).

In related discussions, Michael Zaikin hosted a CHECKSIGFROMSTACK workshop, drawing attention to the collaborative efforts within the Bitcoin development community towards exploring BIP use cases and creating transactions. Future workshops aim to delve into the creation of different types of pools using CTV and CSFS, highlighting ongoing commitments to advancing Bitcoin development ([Workshop Logs](https://ctv-csfs-workshops.github.io/bip348/logs)).

Furthermore, debates around the complexities of payment protocols, specifically comparing MultiPTLCs with traditional PTLCs, emphasize the need for security, privacy, and user experience optimization within blockchain technologies. The discussions explore innovative proposals to enhance transaction efficiency and minimize the necessity for a constant online presence, illustrating a significant shift towards more efficient digital payment systems ([MultiPTLC vs. PTLC](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/multichannel-and-multiptlc-towards-a-global-high-availability-cp-database-for-bitcoin-payments/1983/6)).

recent_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Standard Encrypted Wallet Payload + Standard Encryption Envelope formats
recent_posts.summary:
- Two new Bitcoin Improvement Proposals aim to improve wallet interoperability and security.
- The first proposal introduces a CBOR-based format for wallet data serialization.
- The second proposal suggests a secure container for encrypted wallet data using Argon2id.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 30.0 release candidate is available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v30.0rc1 release candidate is now available.
- Interested parties can download binaries and source code from official links provided.
- Feedback for this release candidate can be submitted on GitHub's issue tracker.

recent_posts.title: IRC logs: BIP 348 Workshop

- Michael Zaikin led a CHECKSIGFROMSTACK workshop for Bitcoin developers on Libera.
- The session explored BIP use cases and transaction creation, with logs available online.
- A future workshop is planned to discuss creating pools with CTV and CSFS.

recent_posts.title: MultiChannel and MultiPTLC: Towards A Global High-Availability CP Database For Bitcoin Payments
recent_posts.summary:
- MultiPTLCs enhance security and reduce the need for constant online presence compared to traditional PTLCs.
- They enable a more efficient transaction process with minimal interaction rounds and autonomous LSP operation.
- The design prioritizes user experience and security, allowing multiple payment attempts with less user involvement.

recent_posts.title: Evolving the Ark protocol using CTV and CSFS
recent_posts.summary:
- The email explores optimizing blockchain transactions by modifying forfeit transaction structures.
- It suggests using key-spend level adaptor signatures for late-binding secrets to improve transaction efficiency.
- Further ideas include transforming 'secret' hashes into curve points and using Alice CSFS signatures for optimization.

recent_posts.title: Stealth addresses using nostr
recent_posts.summary:
- Alice secures key exchanges with Bob through encrypted NIP-17 messages, using a new key.
- The proposal's core seeks clarity on equations and the structural format of public keys.
- It explores reducing Bob's computational load by pre-storing batches of addresses for monitoring.

active_posts.title: A Post Quantum Migration Proposal
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal introduces a phased plan to enhance Bitcoin's defense against quantum threats.
- It suggests transitioning to post-quantum cryptography, setting deadlines for legacy system phase-out.
- Aimed at safeguarding the Bitcoin network, it requires collective stakeholder action for implementation.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] No burn, Quantum Migration Proposal, Quantum Secure Asset Verification & Escrow (QSAVE)
active_posts.summary:
- The QSAVE proposal introduces a novel method to protect Bitcoin from quantum computing threats.
- It aims to secure vulnerable Bitcoins in protective custody, preserving ownership and supporting public welfare.
- The initiative offers a systematic approach to mitigate quantum risks while aligning with Bitcoin’s core principles.

active_posts.title: BIP Booby Trapped Wallets - Covenant-Only Taproot Outputs
active_posts.summary:
- Matias Monteagudo's proposal enhances Bitcoin wallet security via covenant-only Taproot outputs.
- It introduces a mechanism disabling key-path spending, aiming for institutional holder protection.
- The proposal includes a detailed technical specification, ensuring backward compatibility and privacy.

active_posts.title: Sharing block templates
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin nodes and miners are adopting new mempool policies, including full replace-by-fee.
- Compact block relay significantly reduces block propagation times, enhancing network efficiency.
- Proposals like weak blocks and template sharing aim to improve compact block relay and network robustness.

active_posts.title: Addressing community concerns and objections regarding my recent proposal to relax Bitcoin Core's standardness limits on OP_RETURN outputs
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal seeks to relax `OP_RETURN` output limits in Bitcoin, sparking debate.
- Critics worry about data storage misuse, while supporters highlight current inefficiencies.
- The discussion reflects broader challenges in Bitcoin governance and technical evolution.

active_posts.title: Eclipsing Bitcoin Nodes with BGP Interception Attacks
active_posts.summary:
- A stealthier BGP hijacking technique threatens Bitcoin by enabling eclipse attacks on nodes.
- Research shows attackers can hijack Bitcoin traffic via BGP route manipulation, risking double spending.
- Enhanced security strategies, like peer rotation and route-aware peer selection, are crucial for protection.

today_in_history_posts.title: URI scheme for signing and verifying messages
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Arthur Bouquet proposes a new bitcoin URI scheme for easier signature verification.
- His idea requires consensus and suggests using a BIP for community approval.
- Planning to discuss further on Bitcointalk, aiming for wider accessibility in the Bitcoin community.

today_in_history_posts.title: Onion routing design.
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The post proposes a format for onion routing with encryption and padding for security.
- It highlights a vulnerability without MAC, allowing routing manipulation if the destination is guessed.
- Suggests defenses like unique R values and error signing, but notes challenges in fully protecting routes.

today_in_history_posts.title: Covenant tools softfork
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The proposed softfork activates BIP-118, BIP-119, and BIP-345 to enhance Bitcoin security and efficiency.
- BIP-345's implementation into Bitcoin vaults shows significant commercial and personal interest due to its rapid deployment capability.
- With 7,000 lines of code, the manageable review and deployment process for BIP-345 is underway, awaiting community consensus.
